transcript.content: [~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Is this 1955 that you live in?
(laughing) I know! (inaudible) We are knackered. 'cos er, you know - he's not used to work. I've seen him moaning falling asleep. He's not used to it at all.
Sure, and you get on your feet for her for over half an hour.

Yeah, right. So yeah, we didn't even walk around the gold course, we had a buggy. Wasn't even exercise! So we get into conversations, talking, like he's asking me stuff about evolution. What-about-why-tell-me-that, why did the giraffe... "what's that rubbish about the giraffe getting a long neck?" I said "well it didn't try and get a long neck".

"It was selected" and he said "but why would evolution do that?" - I went "Well you're thinking - evolution didn't do anything, there's not there's not this consciousness. There's not this will that a giraffe has to stretch its neck to reach the leaves, one had a long enough neck to survive and pass it on. He was going "Yeah, but why did he evolution?" - but, by the way, this isn't the most stupid thing. This is, this is warming up. This is about quarter to nine. He said "why didn't evolution make a giraffe good at carpentry so it could build a ladder?"
Right... yeah. Okay. No, alright.
Okay, so he's thinkingm he's thinking around it, he's trying to. He's trying to pick holes in evolution.
Yeah.

We got onto - I said, "well yada yada" I was saying umm, erm "we can see the speed of evolution in and lower life forms like bacteria, viruses - they evolved and that's why soon we won't have an antibiotic that didn't kill some certain bacterial strains" and HE said - and this is about half 11 then I said "I'm going to bed ".
HE said "In the future, they reckon that well be able to wake up and eat a yogurt you can have a chat with".
(laughs) I don't know what that means!
Look, lets put on a song on alright.
So you're going to explain that? You've got an explanation?
Yeah.
The Verve - Sonnet
The Verve, Sonnet on Xfm 104.9 I'm Ricky Gervais, with me Steve Merchant and Karl Pilkington.
So let's just get this right. What did Karl say?

He said "they reckon" and he-he-he I said "I'm going to bed". He went "no really", and I said "No I'm going to bed karl, there's no point now because" uh, it' just like "you're talking gobbledygook". You don't mean? I might as well talk to a pot plant plan. He said "In the future, they reckon" -
I don't know who "they" are. I don't know... people who post things on the internet that he reads.
Nah, it was in The Telegraph.
Anyway complete the sentence.

"They reckon the in the future you'll be able to wake up" - I love that there's always a little scenario, an embellishment like this little (whistling) "yawm, hello darling here's your jogurt" - "helloooh". "You'll be able to wake up and eat a yogurt, you can have a chat with"
All right, well - you know. Thanks for that Rick. I'm gonna throw that over to Karl now.
It's when I was away on holiday, right? I got. I don't normally buy The Telegraph...
Too big and that, isn't it? So, but, they were giving it away for free on the plane. So I thought...
Ding dong!

Might as well have it. And I saw a couple of things and I thought "that would be interesting". I saw this thing about the future and it was talking about evolution and what have you - right which I always find weird because I always think that - maybe we've sort of done it wrong anyway. You know what I mean? I sometimes think...
It can't... by definition. Evolution can't get things wrong.
Hmmm...
Things change that it's not successful at, can't pass on its uhh genetic material.
Genetic material or that but... if you're around it's working, if you're around it's working. Slugs are as evolved as they need to be, slugs are as evolved as you... and me.
Well that's true enough!
Yeah, yeah! No disrespect but it works.
Sorry but what's your point Karl?
No I mean I think we probably would have been better off staying as a fish.
*laughs*
Just because there's more water than land, 'int there?
Right.
And we wouldn't drown...
This is why i went to bed
No I can imagine, I'm thinking of dozing off now.
Yeah *laughs*
No but it went- d'you know what I mean? From-
C'mon talk.
It was bacteria, it was fish, mermaid, man
*laughs*
Onward and what have ya.
*laughs* Oh god! Oh god! There are a few knowledge gaps in your theory of evolution.
You generally got it right though.
Basically yeah. It went bacteria, fish, mermaid, man. Ummm, what's next is the big question!

So it was tellin' you all about this and what have you, and sayin' how like we shouldn't have interfered 'cause maybe if we wouldnt't have invented planes and what 'ave ye maybe we'd be able to fly and what 'ave ye-
Sure, yeah.
If we really needed to and stuff like that.
Yeah, okay.
So we've interfered with evolution y'see?
Right.
But then it was sayin' well whats the future got?

Well yes in one way we have interfered with evolution yeah. The evolution of the human being in society is changing, it's not- it's no longer based on the strongest or the fittest because medical science can keep us alive long enough. People can pass on their genetic material, where without this civilisation, they wouldn't have been able to. So yeah, um it- it's- there are different parameters, there are different pressures, there are different things that say whether we're gonna pass on our genertic material or not, okay? So in that sense you're right.
And that , Rick. As far as I'm aware, has led to a yoghurt you can eat and have a conversation with.
So this is what it was sayin' it was just sayin' y'know we're livin' in mad times and that, y'know, there's a lot of weird stuff goin' on.
One of which is:
And the fella was just sayin' uh y'know with computers and stuff like that the way it is, uh, we'll be able to wake up...
Go on
'ave a chat with your yoghurt and 'ave something to eat.
What do you mean have a chat with your yoghurt?!
Because of the amount of- I mean, you have them yoghurts already, those friendly yoghurts. Those bacteria friendly ones, so this is just a really friendly one.
Yeah they don't- *laughs* oh God! I might burst! Do you know what? Sometimes Karl I think we're having a chat with a yoghurt. There can't be any difference!
Yeah but then I'm always reminded that would be more entertaining, that would be more informative.
U2 - city of blinding lights, I'm gonna see them next week, at Twickenham.
Well enjoy that.
Looking forward to it.
Thanks again for letting me know about your uh-
Old nobo and edge and all that. Now listen. You just got an email there saying  "can you turn up your microphone Steve"
Apparently my voice is a little bit quiet.
Karl has to do one thing, make sure we're heard, that's all he has to do.
Well I can hear him. Sounds fine to me.
Hmm well not to the listeners and that's who we're trying to please
Yeah.
One person so they can't even.
Yes, but we've only got one listener, so if he's not happy we're buggered.
(laughs) You allowed to say buggered?
Umm, hmm.
Not twice certainly.
No.
Once could have been a mistake.
Yeah
Twice, pointing it out, is definitely, yeah, complaint material.
Now, Karl. Karl. You haven't told us about your holiday yet. You were meant to do it last week and you didn't.
Uhh.
He started telling us but we didn't have time, 'cause we had to do monkey news about a monkey who was a director who cared about lighting and stuff.
Is there more monkeys news this week?
Yep.
It it where? Ahh, okay, is there, is it real monkey news? Did it happen or is it mostly embellishment in your round, little head?
Its proper stuff. Proper stuff, its proper stuff.
Yep. Okay good. So holiday, where did you go on holiday?
Uhh, Sardinia.
Good?
Yeah, it's alright, yeah. Ahh, nice food an' that. Its important innit?
Yeah
And nice beaches and what have you. I always like a nice, long beach to walk down.
Yeah
But ahh, so we're having a nice walk, right. You know how ahh, nudists do me head in?
Sure.
Right.

Not a problem though is it? It's not like being scared of spiders where they might jump out under the chicken, 'chicken sink?' Kitchen sink at you. You know what I mean. It's not a big problem having your head done in by nudists.
Yeah, but it's just, it just annoys me. It's sort of ruins the day a little bit, 'cause it, it, it makes me uncomfortable.
Right, take clothes off if you feel uncomfortable. That's much more relaxing.
Yeah, but. Well anyway right so I'm walking along the beach, right. Lovely, long beach and what have you. You know, watching the sea, picking up shells and that. Looking at...
Now what are your? What are you wearing? What's your natural beach clobber?

When he say picking up shells I imagine he's like on all fours, going, "ongh, ongh." Like that, you know what I mean, like looking at things. Just like, washing his nuts in the sea, to, to get, to get 'em tasty.
Yeah, going into the sea and then kind of shaking himself and all the water flies off.
(laughs)
I just got you know, flip-flops on, pair of shorts...
Bit noisy flip-flops.
And a, and like a little, a little light shirt.
Sure.
So anyway, walking along and ahh, Suzanne goes, "Oh look." All right. And there's this woman. German I think. Ahh, coming out of the...
How could you tell she was German? Underarm hair?
Well I'll get to it. Forget the underarm hair.
(Laughs)
She came out, it looked like she was smuggling seaweed, right.
(laughs hysterically) I'm going to burst. I am going to burst. Oh god.
And the, the funny thing is, right. She ahh.
Smuggling seaweed. Oh god. She was a bit hairy down there was she?

She, She ahh. It... Mental. I felt bad cause I hadn't had a shave for two days. Right, looked at her. Just, it was ridiculous. She might as well have kept her trunks on. It was just like she was wearing furry trunks, right. So anyway. So, I'm walking along. So.
Yeah, go on then.
So Suzanne's like, "Look" and I'm like, "Oh, not again."
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Or whatever for- for nudes and that.
A nudist colony, sure.
And it's just, that-
Were they playing volleyball?
Well, the annoying thing was... bowls.
Ricky Laughs
Why is that annoying?
Well, don't play a sport where you've gotta bend over.
Ricky Laughs
Neil Young - Pardon My Heart
Neil Young, from the album Zuma, and that's, uh, Pardon My Heart.
Beautiful

On XFM 104.9, Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant, Karl Pilkington. We've just had an E- a text here that says, and I don't know what truth there is in this, as ever, but John says there is apparently a "nude bike ride" today in Hyde Park.
Ricky Groans
Now, I can't believe that's the case because I don't think it's allowed, is it? You can't ride around with your... your veg out can you?
I don't know. I don't know.
Why would you want to?
Well... it's a good point.
On a bike.
Steve Laughs
"On a bike."  I love the fact that that's what disgusts him.

Whoever I- I- I want- do you know what? If we did appeal for a nudist to call in? I'd want a very specific sort. I don't want a little- I want- I want a German nudist. A middle-aged man called Helmut.
Okay.
If there is any- or the closest one to it. So I want a middle-aged man from Germany, if your name is Helmut you're in, but I'll accept... I'll accept Hans, uhm... Carl would be good, wouldn't it?
Okay. All right.
Yeah?
I think, I'm- I'm wondering if the age might... maybe we could- could we- could we broaden that a little bit?
Okay, just a German- a German nudist bloke.
Right.
Could he at least be fat?
Steve Laughs
Okay.
Could I find a fat German fella? If your name's Helmut we're gonna give you a big prize.
Yeah.
But, you know, any fat German fella who likes to get his sausage out.
Sure.
Okay?
His "sauerkraut."
Yeah.
What's the phone number?
Uh, oh eight seven one, triple two, one oh four nine. It would be good just to get an email or a text over the contact, wouldn't it?
Okay.
And then I can just call them up in the week.
Sure.
And, uh...

Eighty three nine three six is the, uh, text number. I think- I mean, I don't know what our, uhm, our audience demographic pans out like, Rick, but I'm suspecting that's probably a fairly small fraction of our listenership, the, uh...
I know, but you know.
The fat German nudists.
There must be someone out there. If you know a fat German who likes to get his tackle out- the phones are going. Phones go-
Straight away. Straight away.
Just answer it, Karl. Just answer it. Just- pot luck. Just-
No, cause it could be anything.
Well let's just see what it is!
No it could be- to be fair, it could be a Nutter. It could be a Nutter.
But just say hello! But just if [unintelligible]
Well if it's important he'll stay there, won't he? He'll stay there.
Well answer it.
Karl Stammers
Let's leave it
Answer it.
Leave it.
Answer it!
Karl Leans Away From the Microphone
Aw, you see this... it's gone. He's gone.
Karl Moves Back Towards the Microphone
There you go, he bottled it, so. Just as well.
Well you took too long to answer it. You don't-
There's a vicar in, uh...
Ricky Sniggers
Australia who's... who's started, sort of, doing his services, and all that, in the nude.
Hot innit though, out there.
Yeah but churches aren't.
Where'd you get this information?
Churches are pretty cold.
Ricky Sniggers
That's, uh- It was on, uh, on some website, which is-
Course it was. Yep.

Just saying about uh, a- a vicar, and that, whose, uh- There's a lot of nudists, and that, who want to get married. Do it. You kno- you know. Don't mess about with the wedding dress, and that, just... just nip up.
Cheaper, innit?
Well, I- I suppose- I suppose it's how, uh- I suppose if you believe in God, you believe that, uh, that's the way to be, innit?
Absolutely.
'Cause "Adam and Eve" and that.
Yeah, but then in Adam and Eve they- the shame made us, uh, dress up didn't it?
Yeah.
Eating the apple and things.
Yeah, but God didn't want that, did he?
No, he wanted to see it all, he was loving it. He's having a whale of a time, getting an eyeful of all of that and then the snake said cover yourself up.
Snake, stitched them right up. So if you believe in God, which clearly I don't, do you believe in God, Karl?
Uh, I dunno, I don't really worry about it, it was ages ago on wasn’t it. So, you know, if He’s about whatever, whatever. I’m not that bothered, Adam and Eve's pretty interesting though, innit? .

Well, how is it interesting? He made, he made, he made man, made out of dust, then he, just because he could, he’s having a laugh. Then he made her outta one of his ribs, again, He liked to vary a little bit. Then they had two sons, which gave rise to the entire human race, what was going on there then?
What would have happened if they didn't go on? That's interesting.

Sometimes with pandas they don't fancy the other one, do they? They go, “Well, that's my choice, one? You’ve brought me one Panda from Lisbon Zoo and I've got to shag that? What if I don't fancy em?” What if they bring in a right, a right slapper?
Do you think that?-
What if it’s the equivalent of like, Love Island?
Well I imagine it was like Celebrity Love Island
Yeah, and they're going like, “I'm not shagging that slapper, every, every panda in the world has seen that dirty old mot in magazines. Why am I meant to mate with it? I've got some dignity”
Are you talking about Adam there or Panda there, or both? Either is fine I suppose.
(Laughs) Pandas

Do you think Adam had any say when God was making Eve? Was he saying, “Can you make, make, the boobs a bit bigger, would you?. I'm sorry but I’m a bit of a blond guy, I’m into blonds really. Sorry. I don't know, did he have any input, or was it just?
I don’t know, Well, I suppose...
Well, it was one of his ribs.
I know, but he's probably restricted you know. “Well, I'm working with a rib, Adam. Give me a break, there's only so many things I can do.”
Well he was probably, is probably in kind of intensive care with, with the whole thing.
They go, “Well I can’t just keep making the boobs and things bigger because her legs will get shorter and I don’t want short legs.”
Well, make her legs longer.
I don’t mind no legs, I don’t mind no legs.
As long as the boobs are sizable.
I’ll tell ya, I’ll tell ya what’s weird though Steve, everyone's heard of like Adam and Eve, Yeah? What's the surname?
Yeah, where’d they get their post from, unbelievable?

Now, listen, before you play the next tune. We should, just, we were trying to mop up some stuff from the last couple of shows which we haven't dealt with yet. One of which is an obsession of yours because, we’re on a radio station.

Ricky and I, we come in, we bring in CDs, music we love, it means so much to us. We adore it. You, You don't really care about music, you work at a radio station, it's just, eh, you know, I don't care.
No, I do, I do
No you don't
I do like a good track. I don't like everything that comes out and everyone Raves about

Yeah, you thought the iPod wasn't worth it because you can you name the five tracks you'd like, what was it? It was, In the Ghetto, Babushka, Living in the City. What was the other one, Killing of Georgie? And there was one other one, something, and you just only like songs with a story.
Yeah, But then there's a reason to listen to it
No, only once
No, because you might forget the ending, listen to it again?
Well you might.
Anyway, you've been listening to Babushka quite a lot, is the right? It really got into your head. Now, you're trying to decipher the story.

When I've been sort of asking for songs with stories, people will text and email in, whatever, and I've had I've had a couple, you know, last time we did the show, so I've gone, ah right that sounds interesting, and Babushka when I was away on holiday, I listened to a few times because I like the story. It's got a little story going on.
You got some thoughts on it, though, have you?
Uhhh?
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Half Light by Athlete on Xfm 104.9. Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant, and Karl Pilkington. Karl.
Right.
Two o'clock. Let's get rockbusters rolling.

I should just um, if people aren't familiar with rockbusters, then uh, someone has actually sent in one of their own to test Karl. Um, they've used, I think, the same principle that Karl has, which is,
Interesting.
You know, utterly random.
Yeah.
Well as you've said before -
Tenious.
Really, just, just,
Not really cryptic.
Just try and think of something that he might be thinking of.
Yeah, sure, sure, sure.
So um, I'm gonna, I mean, she's done it quite coherently but I'm wondering if I should sort of say it more as Karl might say it, you know, just slightly less.
Well, different every time.
Yeah, slightly less coherent. So um, Karl, this is one for you, alright?
Go on.

You know, it's Sunday morning. You know, um, just, you know, I'm in bed, but I want to sleep. You know, but like Hollyoaks is on, the Omnibus, I'm just watching that, you know. Um, I've got to make a lovely cup of tea.
You know, in the bed with Suzanne, aren't I? Having a cup of tea.
What's going on there?

Just watching the telly and that, but hang on. I ain't got anything to dunk in me uh, in my tea. Haven't anything to dunk in my tea, have I? You know, I haven't got anything to dunk in there, and I'm just having, you know, what, what am I doing?
Is it L B?
It's L R.
Oh.
L R. So, have a think about that one, Karl.
Ah, I think I know it.
Do yah?
Yeah? Go for it.
Go on.
Is it Lionel Rich, Richie?
It is Lionel Richie. What's your logic?
Sort of, lying in, lying ill. And it's like,
No, no rich tea. No rich tea.
Yeah.
No biscuits. No rich tea. Lying no rich tea. Lyin-ill Rich-tea. Lionel Richie. It works, it's just as, just as incoherent as with yours.
We've done one, we've done one a bit like it.
What's that?
We've done one a little bit like it. There's naught wrong with that.
I cannot believe you got it.
So that's, that's the type of stuff.
He got it instantly.
I cannot believe you got it.
I might not have got it without the initials but that's why we chuck them in, just to help you along.
Ricky laughs.
Christ, what've you got for us this week?
Right, so we got, we got three of them.

Oh, by the way, don't bother calling in, Kate Bush, cause Karl doesn't want to answer the phones. He says "Kate Bush is not gonna call so he says we're all gonna be nutters" so we apologize. He's got one thing to do. He didn't even get the sound right cause someone's complained about they couldn't hear Steve. He's gotta do monkey news, which is always twaddle. And he won't even answer the phones now, so I don't know, I don't know why he gets paid. He takes off Mondays -
I don't.
Cause he works Saturdays -
I don't.
He gets paid for Saturdays. He takes five weeks holiday a year.
Not off Mondays. Not off Mondays anymore.
And it, and he moans.
Not off Mondays.
Steve chuckles.
Well.
Right, uh.
Rockbusters. What've you got for us?
Right then, the first one. Uh, there's a vehicle that sells kebabs. Alright?
Ricky and Steve deeply inhale and laughs.
Alright.
There's a vehicle that sells kebabs. Initial D. Right? D.
Great.
Alright? You worked that one out?
Of course I haven't!
Alright, the second one. Um, you're asked if you want that bit of the egg.
Ricky and Steve laugh.
You what? You what? You what?
You're asked if, if you want that bit of the egg.
Yeah.
You think about it, but be uh, sort of decide against it.
And again?
What's going on there? You're asked if you want that bit of the egg. You think about it but you go "nah, I'll go against it." Right?
I've, I've got it. Is it -
Whoa.
W Y O
Yeah.
Got it.
Alright, so.
Okay.
Yeah.
That one, that one works.
Mmm uhh.
No it doesn't. No it doesn't. No it doesn't.
Uhh and the last one. I don't think this bird -
Burger will catch on.
I don't think this burger will catch on.
Yeah. And the letter there is M. So you just, uh, text or email in, uh, with the answers and uh, win some stuff. What've we got?
We've got some prizes. We've got another box set of The League of Gentlemen.
This is instant gratification but uh, you go into a draw for some, something bigger so what've we got today?

Yeah, well today, this is what you're taking home today. Uh, you've got The League of Gentlemen, the complete collection on DVD. That's not, that's worth having, definitely. Uh, we've got Catterick, which is the current Vic and Bob shellbooths two, which is uh, good. The Aviators, the um, the award winning, um, the
Um, the Leonardo DiCaprio Martin Scorsese biopic, and once again, Ladder 49.
We're giving that away again, are we?
Yeah, yeah, apparently we've got
Oh, can we get a job load of those, have we?
We've got loads of them!
Oh! Excellent!
Yeah so email in if you just want a copy of Ladder 49. I'm sure we can dig one out for you.
Yeah, yeah. Or phone in cause Karl does not answer the phones.
Alright.

And remember the winner goes forward in a chance to win the big prizes. The signed homer drawing, the signed Nigel Tufnel poster. If you go to ricky gervais dot com and see Matt Groening actually drawing that.
To uh, to verify it. A bit of Lloyd Cole won't, never hurt anyone, has it?
Lloyd Cole - Impossible Girl
Lloyd Cole Impossible Girl on Xfm 104.9. Well.
Rick, I'm just reading an email we've had and it is indeed true. Scores of naked cyclists will be wheeling around London today in a mass protest against oil dependency.
The World Naked Bike Ride will see the arresting sight of up to 200 daring riders bearing all in their cycle past some of the capital's most famous landmarks.
Have they got to wear an helmet? Are they against wearing a helmet?
Well, I don't, I, I think they're trying to make a statement, I would imagine. I don't know.
Well, they don't have to wear a helmet. It's not law to wear a helmet on a bike, is it?It's for your own safety; it's sensible. You're right, yeah.
Well it's also sensible to just pop some pants on.
Ricky and Steve laugh.
Just pop some pants on.
Are you going, are you going to be popping down there and cheering them on?
I'm not, I'm not going anywhere near it.
What, What're they going against? What's the problem that's going on?
Um, oil dependency? I think generally, we're consuming too much oil, aren't we, in the world and it's gonna run out one day.
Talking of um, campaigns and uh, things and that. Um, did you see um, Sir Bob on um,  Jonathan Ross last night?
Sir Bob Geldof?
Sir Bob Geldof. Uh, um, you're gonna walk to uh, Edinburgh or South of France, Karl? What'd you think of all this, the G8?
Uh, I think it's good that, you know, he's, uh, he's doing some stuff for the world and what have you, but probably won't, won't bother -
Right.
- having a walk.
What'd you make of all this, all this campaigning? You know, he's dedicated his life to this now, hasn't he?
Yeah, yeah, I mean, it's interesting. I was watching him last night. Uh, I respect the man. I mean, he used to work here, didn't he? Did some shows and that.
Mmhmm.
It's good. It's alright that, that he can do it, but -
I assume that's not why you respect him. I assume you respect him cause he's trying to save a nation as opposed to 'used to work at Xfm for a while'.
Yeah, I know, but I'm just, I'm just saying is, uh
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
The phone number, what's the phone number?
Can't we talk to him next week?
He might be busy next week.
No.
He's got stuff to organize.
Don't, don't worry about it. Don't worry about it. He can talk to us next week, alright? I'm not gonna go and go through the phones. It's mental.
Ricky laughs.
Play a record.
Alright. What're we having? A bit of uh, Killer?
Yeah.
The Killers - Somebody Told Me
The Killers Somebody Told Me on Xfm 104.9. Tell you what - talking of um, starving. I went to what is meant to be the best restaurant in the world on uh,
Oh yeah?
On Wednesday, yeah.
Sure.
Um.
You must be famished.
Uh, well, Jonathan uh, Ross, uh, booked a table there. It came out, I think he's been trying to get there for a while, and uh, um, I think he said waiting list and everything, right, and uh,
What, you've got to be walking straight in.
You can always walk straight in with that.
Yeah.
Yeah.
And uh, uh, me and Jane went along with him and Jane to The Fat Duck in Bray. It was voted the best restaurant in the world.
Right.

Okay. And um, it was incredible. I mean, it's a cross between a restaurant and sort of barnum. They take you, just, incredible, but all the way there, I'm thinking well I, I, I can't eat stuff in normal restaurants. I can't eat, I don't eat red meat. I'm squeamish about things like seafood. Anything, anything that's a little, got too many legs, or was a crustacean once, or feeds on worms.
I, it was, I knew that one of their, um, signature dishes was snail porridge. So I'm thinking "I'm not gonna be able to eat anything here." So I'm thinking I had something to eat before I went.
Good thinking.

I was thinking that they better not have mucked around the bread, right? Got there. Beautiful. Um, and uh, it was, it was, it was really quite fantastic. And, and I let them know straight away, um, that I was a philistine and they really accommodated me, you know. I didn't have the snail porridge.

They put um, mushrooms in my snail porridge, which was more risotto, and its tasting menus and that, and it was, it was, um, uh, really fantastic. But, Jonathan halfway through on the way there, I don't like travel well, on the way there, he actually phoned me and said "Why are we taking you to this restaurant?"
Good point. Very good point.
Uh, uh, they know even if I go around there, they cook me sausage and mash.
Yeah.
Or, do you know what I mean?
Well, you are, you have the palette of one of those kids from the Jamie Oliver school dinners program.
Ricky laughs.
Whose, they've's got the lovely Jamie Oliver cooked, you know, kind of uh, Ratatouille.
Yeah, yeah.
But they're going for this sort of chicken twizzlers.

Well there's nothing wrong with chicken, I like chicken. I like, I chicken I can eat. I'm squeamish about red meats. There's nothing I've, it's a mixture of it's not uh, it's not morals. There's only one thing I don't eat morally and that's veal. But the other thing else is that if it's got eyes and legs and things sticking out of it or if it's pink -
But it hasn't got eyes or legs and things sticking out of it!
I know but -
What are you talking about?
I,
I mean, it just infuriates me. I actually got to a point now where I can't,

I refuse to eat out with Ricky cause I can't, it just sucks the life out of me. It actually makes me depressed. I can't enjoy the experience. If you go to an awards do, they bring out a lovely grub, lovely food, you know three courses.
Always lamb.
And you're whinging.
Always salmon!
And you're always whinging!
Which is hardly cooked, followed by lamb.
Lovely bit of lamb! Who doesn't think lamb is the best of all the meats?!
Ohhhhh.
And you just, you whinge, you complain, you look at Jane like a little boy who's like "ohhh mom why have you brought me here?"
Ricky laughs.
You are just, oh, and I tell yah, I put it, I don't, I don't want to

You know, bad mouth people, but I suspect it's your family. I suspect it was your upbringing. I imagine, you know, I imagine it, if I came to your house, you know, late 60's, early 70's, came around to your place in Reading, it would have just been the smell of chip fat.
Hold on.
Just everywhere. Prevailing, just one of those chip fat fryers that's just yellow, it's like constantly. 24 hours -
But I used to eat things.
- a day, just bubbling away.

But I used to eat beef and pork and that and, I used to have to, eventually, when I was getting sort of squeamish and getting older, I'd make it burn it so much that it was just like chewing on a piece of leather anyway. Where I couldn't, I couldn't stand it if there's the sight of blood or something.
A salad in your house would have been.
I'll tell you what a salad is.
A pickled onion and a packet of crisps.

No, a salad in my house, right, when it was summer, we're out in the garden, a lovely salad, grated cheese, grated egg, two bits of beet root that you leave, um, uh, a pickled onion, and a packet of crisps.
Steve laughs.
And uh, that was, that was uh, that was a salad. But -
Now is that, is that, do you agree that that is probably the reason why you've got this, this, this, this palette, and I don't even -
No, I, I, I, I -
It's not even a palette. That's too loathesome of a word to use for it.
I've got more squeamish as I've got olderer. Cause I say I used to, I used to eat beef or pork, or -
But what do you mean squeamish?! I don't understand what you mean, squeamish?
If I suddenly think about it, I can eat, I can eat like, uh, but cooked, like uh.
It has to be blasted, it has to be unrecognizable an animal, you know, I mean, I mustn't see a bit of pink or a bit of fat, or -
So if we, if we were in biblical times, -
Yeah.
And you're there, and Jesus Christ has just fed 40,000 with some fishes and some loaves, you'd be going "I'm not into the fish, JC" and -
I'd say "take the head off, cook, really cook, take the skin off, there's, I can see a bit of spine, and while you're gutting -
Unless that bread is mighty white, I'm not interested.
Yeah no.
Ricky laughs.
Yeah, but the thing is what he hasn't said is well, um.

He gets frustrated to have to go from restaurant to restaurant for something I can eat, but the reason we've only got about three restaurants to choose from, at that, because he doesn't wanna spend more than a fiver at lunchtime.
At lunchtime!
Mmm.
If I was going out of an evening, you'd spend a decent about of wallop. But -
Mmm.
Lunchtime?
Would yah?

Why'd you spend, you'd be happy to spend 20 quid! On lunch! Imagine that every single day. There's no one out there who's eating lunch, 20 quid a day on lunch. It's crazy, you don't need that much food at lunchtime. Cause we, I'm, I'll tell you what happens. You go in there, you have some kind of, you know, Thai green curry for lunch. You're asleep by 1:30. We're trying to work!
We're trying to write TV shows and you're dozing off like one of those giant anacondas that's just eaten a sheep.
Ricky laughs.
And it's slowly digesting it, it takes like 3 weeks.
He doesn't, he, Karl, he does not like to spend, he, he, he'll go, he'll walk a mile out of his way to get a sandwich, or -
And having that argument over that 50 p that time, right?
Ricky laughs.
I don't want to bring that back up again, but -

No. Here's the situation, Karl. I leant you 50 p and you decided you weren't going to pay me back. It should be to my discretion if I say "don't worry about it, Karl." You should offer me the 50 p, go "there's that 50 p I owe you", and I'll go "don't worry about it, Karl". But you didn't even do that!
Nah, it's the way that you were like -
I said "where's my 50 p?" You went "oh you don't need that." That's not your decision to have!
I didn't, I didn't say that. I said "I, I'm, I don't think I've got it at the moment." Or whatever.
Mmm.
Rubbish.
And going through me pockets and that for 50 p. Ridiculous.
You've just given him a keg of beer for free, haven't yah?
Well, let's not go over it again. I mean -

I just, I just think that value for money is important. Like, now, okay, so for instance in the morning, I have to get the tube. But you can get a, a, a travel card, zones 1 and 2, right? It's about 4 pounds 70, I think. But, before 9:30, It's about 6 pounds 50.

Alright and then at 9:30, when the clock literally on the clock ticks over to 9:30, it's 4 pounds 70, right? Now, sometimes I'll get there, I'll be about 20 past 9. Now you'd be saying to me, "aw, just spend it, just spend it." And I'm thinking, I've got 10 minutes, I'll perhaps read the paper, wait for it to click over to 9:30, and then I'll get a cheaper ticket. Now surely, that makes sense! Surely, that's logic.
Mmm.
Don't you, I mean if you were in that situation, Rick, if you were there, right, and you had, let's say you had three minutes to wait before 9:30, what would you do? Would you stand there and wait?
No cause waiting to me is worse than anything.
It's madness. It's madness.
I can't stand queuing, I can't stand, no, no, I'll pay yeah.
How long would it have to be before you'd wait?
I, I, I mean -
If there was a minute on the clock to go, would you wait?
Uh, if they literally said "if you wait 30 seconds", it's, I'd, I'd go "um, alright."
Well that is the case. That literally is the case.
Yeah, okay, but not ten minutes, no. Not worth it.
What'd about you, Karl?
Uh.
I'd feel flash, if it was 30 seconds, I'd feel flash going "I'd spend 3 pounds" but if it was like a couple of minutes, I'd go "Ah, it doesn't matter", I, you know. I just, I just wouldn't.
Madness.
Yeah.
Think about how that tops up over the years.
Amazing. Karl -
What about you, Karl, would you do it?

It, it depends wouldn't it, what your job is and that, if you're a doctor, you've got to get to, you know, go and save someone, or whatever, you can't say "aw just ten minutes." Depends. Depends on the situation, depends. Most of the time, I've got to get in work early, I can't be hanging around til half 9 -
Well you don't though, do you? I've, I've, I've called him around to film -
So you know, I've got stuff to do. The film and that.
And he was, uh, he was, I've seen him do one day, right? I've seen him for one whole day. He went away, he fell asleep at, um, quarter to 8 in the bath cause he was knackered.
Karl moans.
So, you know, he has 5 weeks holiday a year, he's taking the piss.
Forget it.
Feeder - Pushing the Senses
Feeder - Pushing the Senses. Quite a food related sort of, uh, show, isn't it?
It is, and thinking of gluttony, did you see in, uh, I think it was Heat magazine, um, it was former pop idol winner Michelle McManus.
Oh yeah.
She's lost considerate, she's lost a lot of weight.
Oh yeah, she's lost 5 stone, hasn't she?
Uh, so, basically the headline was, um, "I used to eat, uh, 12 packets of Doritos a night". At night. 12 packets of Doritos.
I just like the idea that you've got to 11 packets and you're thinking -
One more will do it.
Still, still a bit peckish.
One more will do it.
Yeah.
Steve laughs.
Ohh.
Unbelievable. But someone sent in a couple of odds and ends, news stories you know, they've gleaned off the web. And apparently, uh, Britian's fattest family have shed 23 stone. Um, they uh -
What, one of them died?
Between the five of them - oh come on - between the five of them, the Phillips family from Worcester weighed more than a hundred stone. Jesus, and -
Well, how many are there?
They spent - there're 5 of them - they spent 300 pounds a week on food.

Um, an evening meal consisted of an all-you-can-eat Chinese buffet and another ice cream stop at McDonald's. Uh, the mom, she was generally happy, like Carly's, but she said she used to get upset when she couldn't, um, buy clothes for kids because the shops didn't stock anything above XXXXXL. Um, but uh -
Ricky snorts.
It says here that, it says Mitchell, 13, was the heaviest of the three, weighing at 27 stone by the age of 4. He was Britain's fattest toddler weighing 10 stone.
Is that competition still going?
He broke five bikes.
He broke five bikes by uh, buckling the wheels.
Oh, that's embarrassing.
I know you're not a fan of fat kids, Karl.
Chasing an ice cream van.
Yeah.
But the bike just fell apart.
Yeah.
Well.
Maybe now he's on that nude, uh, bike ride, you know, cause he's lost some weight.
Oh, that would be painful, wouldn't it?
That would, that would be extraordinary.
If one of them buckles.
Yeah.
Well, I've got another food-related, uh, IM here. Now, Karl, I got a little email via my agent sent from someone here. Okay, so sent from someone at, um, Xfm. Okay, and

She just said uh, "I thought, um, this might be, ah, good for Ricky to use on Saturday." And, obviously what happened is Suzanne has sent you an email in the week, it was Wednesday, and you've returned it, but I think you returned it to the wrong email address. You returned it to someone here who, of course, immediately forwarded it to my agent for ridicule on the show. Don't panic. It's nothing that bad. Okay.
It's an email from Suzanne talking about your tea that night. Was Suzanne out on Wednesday night?
Was the, uh, an England game, or summit?
Yeah. So, so you were alone, you were home alone, were you Wednesday night?
Yeah.
Did you enjoy your meal? Was it, was it a quiche?
Go on.
Right. From Suzanne. To Karl.

Take the quiche and put it on the baking tray. Cook for 30 minutes on a hundred and ninety. Take lettuce and put on plate. Take 3 tomatoes, wash, and chop into quarters. Place on lettuce. Take an avocado, chop in half, remove the stone.
Ricky and Steve laugh.
Peel skin and slice. Place on salad. Put salt and pepper on and a dribble of olive and balsamic vinegar dressing.
Right. In brackets, small bottle behind the cafetiere. Right, in case he's reaching for bleach.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Right, that's a, you have to put everything else away. Right, then sprinkle a smidge of parmesan on top. Remove quiche from oven. Cut into quarters and put on plate. Eat.
Oh wow.
Ricky laughs.
Does she have to do that every single time she's out?
Look at his face!
No, it's just that, I'm not that good at cooking, right? Umm, and to be honest, that, that was a lot of hard work.
I didn't bother warming it up.
Ricky wheezes, laughs, and bangs on the table.
And I did without the avocado.
Why? Why?
Too much messing about.
Ricky laughs.
He didn't even do that. With instructions, it was too much.
But uh, yeah I'm not that, I'm not that good at cooking and that.
Did you genuinely, that's not cooking though, is it, Karl? That's just slicing -
Just heating up a quiche. That's, cooking it is making the quiche.
Yeah, but I'm, I'm just, I can't, I can't be bothered.
Do you, could you have figured that out if she hadn't left that note for you?
Why does she have to tell you what the olive oil and balsamic vinegar was?
Because I've, I've, I've put sort of cooking oil on me food once and I've said alright that's a bit -
Ricky wheezes and laughs.
It's ever since, right -
I'm gonna die.
Wow.
Year, years ago -
I'm gonna die.
Years ago -
Oh god like leaving a Mr. McGill at home. I just -
It was, it was ever since I put sausages in the toaster that, uh,
Ricky and Steve laugh
Oh god, what do you mean?
I nearly -
What do you mean?
I nearly set my flat on fire. Cause d'you know like when you're grilling food in a pan and all that?
Yeah.
Sort of sausages spit and it goes everywhere, dunnit? And it makes everywhere greasy.
Ricky wheezes.
Sausages in a toaster.
So I thought, well, just wanted to warm em up.
Yeah.
Put em in the toaster.
Yeah.
What happened?
And she sort of caught while she -
They got stuck and then sort of caught on fire, I'd imagine.
She, she, well, she came in just as I was sort of plunging it. And what have you. Came in from work, said "what are you doing? what are you-?" and I said "I'm having sausages."
Ricky wheezes.
"Well the oven isn't on." "I know, they're in here." "What're you - turn it off!" Panicking and that.
Ricky laughs.
But, I've had, I've never been into it. I've never been into cooking and that. School and stuff, I didn't bother doing it.
Oh god, oh, every time Suzanne comes home, she must think "please be the house still there."
Yeah.
"Please, please don't let me hear a fire engine."
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

And it’s to win the signed Homer, saying, “I like Karl because he’s stupid like me” and you can see Matt Groening drawing that to know it's real at rickygervais.com, and you can win that and a signed Nigel Tufnel poster.
It’s a Ricky and Steve Classic on Xfm, Sugar - “If I Can't Change your Mind”
Brilliant.
So listen, it’s time isn’t it? We've only got a few minutes left, so you better play the jingle
Oh, chimpanzee that, monkey news.
So monkey news, if you've only just started listening to the show, Oh you poor fool, monkey news is where Karl reports for us all the latest monkey activity

A headline or a word or someone- something overhead in a pub and then totally embellishes it and makes it ridiculous and impossible. He believes it though. He believes every word he's saying, let me say that. Before you hear - when you hear this, whatever it is - I haven't heard it - twattle - remember Karl totally believes it, Go on...
Right? So anyway, right, I think it's in, ah, in LA this happened.
“I think”, why’s he think?
So these people are in a restaurant having a lovely meal
Is one of them short and hairy, but it goes-
Totally covered from top to bottom in a space suit, so they didn't know it was a monkey?
It's not one of the customers, one of the waiters?
So they’re having a lovely dinner. Probably one of the best sort of dinners have had, right. So the waiter comes over and it's like, you know, “Can we just say that we’ve had a lovely meal and that-”
Right, It's the chef
Course it is, can we see the chef.
Yeah.
So can we just, you know, see, see the guy that cooked it. Yeah.
‘Course
Yeah, short fella, hairy, wearing a balaclava.
Don’t say much
To be honest the waiter said look, he's busy, he’s got meals to cook, and what have you , he hasn’t really got time. They said, “it’ll only take a minute”- he said, No, I prefer-“
So this is a restaurant in LA that serves brilliant food?
“I'll pass your message on and what-have-you, right? So, umm...
So he sends for Monkey P.A.Y.
It’s a bit odd. Anyway, So, they go out, they go out to the car and they notice the kitchen doors open.

Yeah, of course they do because they’re going to discover something I don't know. Hold on, just, just out of interest where’d this Chef train? Before, before we see him or reveal, you know, what he might look like or like to eat.
So anyway, so so they pop their head in think we'll just we'll just nip in and go “love, love, love the fruit salad whatever”
“We better see the human chef”
You’ll never guess what.
Go on-
Monkey stood on a chair, right, cooking veg. All right. So anyway, so they’re like, “what’s going on there?”
What do you mean he’s cooking veg, what’s he doing with it?
He’s stood on a chair by the cooker, and he's chopping, chopping.
He’s chopping as well, there’s a little embellishment

It's got a little, you know- it's got the bosses in there. They’re like a bit shocked, so he's a bit panicking, because you've got this monkey working for him. So they say to him, ‘What's going on here. We didn't know this, this is what's going on. You know, why have you got a monkey cooking stuff.” So he said well-
Incidentally, a monkey, I should point out that probably doesn't need instructions from its girlfriend.
Oh, Forget it.

synopsis.description: In the future, they reckon that we'll be able to wake up and eat a yogurt you can have a chat with.
